case_vignette: A 36-year-old female with a history of end stage renal disease secondary to poorly controlled type I diabetes on peritoneal dialysis presents to her nephrologist's office with chest pain, shortness of breath, and extreme fatigue. She has a history of inadequate dialysis due to poor compliance. In the office, the patient's vitals are BP: 94/58; HR: 90; RR: 20; T: 98.0 F. EKG is shown below (Figure A). The patient is immediately taken to the emergency department.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having chest pain, difficulty breathing, and feeling extremely tired.
Great, thank you for letting me know. Can you tell me more about the chest pain? Is it a sharp or dull ache? Does it radiate to any other part of your body?
The chest pain feels like a constant ache and it hasn't spread to any other parts of my body.
Okay, that's helpful to know. Have you noticed any other symptoms, such as shortness of breath, lightheadedness, or nausea?
Yes, I've been experiencing shortness of breath as well.

Great, that helps to narrow it down. Have you noticed any triggers for your symptoms, such as exertion, stress, or certain activities? And have you had any recent changes in your medications or supplements?

Okay, that's good to know. Based on what you've told me, I would like to order some additional tests to help confirm the diagnosis. Would you be willing to undergo an electrocardiogram (ECG) and a blood test to check your cardiac enzymes?
I've just had an EKG done at my doctor's office before coming here.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on the ECG results, I would like to schedule a stress test for you to further evaluate your cardiac function. Would you be willing to undergo a stress test?

Also, I would like to know if you have any history of heart disease or if you have any family history of heart disease.
Yes, I'm willing to undergo a stress test, but I don't have a history of heart disease myself or in my family.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms and the results of your ECG, I suspect that you may be experiencing a condition called coronary artery disease. This is a condition where the arteries that supply blood to the heart become narrowed or blocked, which can cause chest pain or discomfort.

To confirm the diagnosis, I would like to schedule a stress test for you. During the test, you will be connected to an electrocardiogram machine and will be asked to exercise on a treadmill or stationary bike while we monitor your heart rate and rhythm. This will help us determine if there is any evidence of reduced blood flow to the heart muscle.

If the test reveals any abnormalities, we may need to perform additional tests such as an echocardiogram or a cardiac catheterization to further evaluate your heart function.

Do you have any questions about the stress test or the next steps?
No questions, I understand the need for the stress test and am ready for the next steps.

Great, thank you for your cooperation. Based on the results of the stress test, we may need to take additional steps to evaluate and treat your condition. This may include medication to help manage your symptoms, lifestyle changes to reduce your risk factors, or further testing such as an echocardiogram or cardiac catheterization.

I will discuss the results of the stress test with you in more detail and recommend the appropriate course of action. In the meantime, please continue to take your medication as prescribed and follow any lifestyle changes that we have discussed.

Is there anything else you would like to ask or discuss?
No, thank you, I don't have any more questions right now.

Great, thank you for letting me know. I will be in touch with you soon to discuss the results of the stress test and any further recommendations for your care. In the meantime, please feel free to reach out to me if you have any questions or concerns.

Thank you for choosing our cardiology practice for your care. We are here to help you manage your heart health and provide the best possible care.

Have a great day!

I understand. Non-compliance with dialysis treatment can have serious consequences for your health. Dialysis helps to remove waste products and excess fluids from your blood when your kidneys are no longer able to do so. If you're not going to your dialysis sessions as prescribed, your blood may become too concentrated with waste products, which can lead to a range of complications, including infection, muscle cramps, and heart problems.

It's important to talk to your doctor about any challenges you're facing in following your treatment plan.
